<p>
<a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?city=washington" rel="city">WASHINGTON</a>, May 28, <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?year=1830">1830</a>. 
</p><p>
DEAR SIR: Circumstances which I need not explain render it necessary 
for me, in self defence, to call on you for a statement of my course in the 
meeting of the cabinet, in the summer of <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?year=1818">1818</a>, on the Seminole war. I 
wish you also to state, whether a private letter from Gen. Jackson to Mr Monroe, such as discovered in the enclosed extract of a letter from 
Mr. Crawford to <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?tla=jof" rel="colleague met">Mr. Forsyth</a>, was before the cabinet during the deliberation, or 
whether any allusion was made to any letter of that description. 
</p><p>
With sincere regard, 
</p><p>
I am, &c. &c. 
</p><p>
<a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?tla=jcc" rel="me">J. C. CALHOUN</a>.

Hon. <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?tla=wiw" rel="met colleague">Mr. Wirt</a>. 
</p>
